title: A “slow bleed” of funding threatens NASA’s science flagships
summary: NASA’s overall science budget in the FY25 request is nearly $1 billion less than what the agency expected last year it would have available. While MSR’s problems has attracted the most attention, the pain is being felt across the science mission directorate.

title: NASA Sets Path to Return Mars Samples, Seeks Innovative Designs
summary: The agency is asking the NASA community to work together to develop a revised plan that leverages innovation and proven technology.

title: Space Force eyes faster satellite development with commercial tech
summary: Space Systems Command’s program executive officer Cordell DeLaPena says large, expensive satellites will be ‘disaggregated’

title: New upper stage disposal rules will help, not harm, U.S. leadership in space
summary: New safety regulations on the safe disposal of upper stages will help U.S. leadership in space, regardless of industry pushback.

title: China launches commercial SuperView-3 remote sensing sat
summary: China continued construction of a commercial constellation of remote sensing satellites early Monday with the launch of the SuperView-3 (01) satellite.

title: EU to delay space law, constellation contract
summary: The European Commission is delaying two key space initiatives, a space law and a contract for a satellite constellation, until at least this summer.

title: NASA document outlines selection of lunar rover companies
summary: NASA documents show how the agency balanced cost, capabilities and experience in its selection of three companies to continue work on an Artemis lunar rover.

title: Australian Minister Questions Involvement in ESA Astronaut Training
summary: Australia's Minister for Industry and Science, David Shoebridge has questioned the cost and potential return on investment of one of its citizens taking part...

title: Space Force acquisition command prioritizing speed and commercial partnerships
summary: Lt. Gen. Philip Garrant, head of Space Systems Command: “We have a lot of new work coming. I've got to be able to support all these new mission growth areas’

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy April 14-20, 2024
